inputFields.name: balanceUTCOffset
inputFields.description:
Use this field to specify a timezone for queries to your Ledger. 

When aggregating balances, all transactions within a 24 hour period starting at midnight UTC are included in each day. 
You can specify a different starting hour for balances. For example, use "-08:00" to align balances with Pacific Standard Time. 
Balance queries would then consider the start of each local day to be at 8am UTC the next day in UTC. 
The default timezone is UTC.

args.name: consistencyMode
args.description:
- eventual: Returns an eventually consistent balance, even if the Ledger Account's `ownBalanceUpdates` in its `consistencyConfig` is `strong` (default).
- strong: Returns a strongly consistent balance or an error if the Ledger Account's `ownBalanceUpdates` in its `consistencyConfig` is `eventual`.
- use_account: Returns a strongly consistent balance if the Ledger Account's `ownBalanceUpdates` in its `consistencyConfig` is `strong` and an eventually consistent balance otherwise.

args.description: The currency of the balance to query. Required if the account is a multi-currency Ledger Account.

fields.description: How much did the this ledger account's ownBalance change during the specified period. This query will exclude all child accounts.

args.description: The currency of the balance change to query. Required if the account is a multi-currency Ledger Account.

args.name: period
args.description: Specifies the period of time over which this query will calculate the balance difference e.g. 1969 or 1969-Q3 or 1969-07 or 1969-07-21 or 1969-07-21T02

fields.name: ownBalanceChanges
fields.description: How much did the this ledger account's ownBalance change during the specified period. This is the total of all lines in this ledger account, excluding all child ledger accounts

args.name: period
args.description: Specifies the period of time over which this query will calculate the balance difference e.g. 1969 or 1969-Q3 or 1969-07 or 1969-07-21 or 1969-07-21T02

fields.name: ownBalances
fields.description: Total of all lines across all currencies in this ledger account, excluding all child ledger accounts

args.name: at
args.description: Provide a timestamp to get this balance at a specific logical time. If not specified, the latest value will be returned e.g. 1969 or 1969-07 or 1969-07-21 or 1969-07-21T02

args.name: consistencyMode
args.description:
- eventual: Returns an eventually consistent balance, even if the Ledger Account's `ownBalanceUpdates` in its `consistencyConfig` is `strong` (default).
- strong: Returns a strongly consistent balance or an error if the Ledger Account's `ownBalanceUpdates` in its `consistencyConfig` is `eventual`.
- use_account: Returns a strongly consistent balance if the Ledger Account's `ownBalanceUpdates` in its `consistencyConfig` is `strong` and an eventually consistent balance otherwise.

fields.name: parentLedgerAccountId
fields.description: ID of the parent ledger account of this ledger account

fields.name: path
fields.description:
The unique Path of the ledger account. This is a slash-delimited string containing the location of an account in its chart of accounts.
For accounts created with a schema, this will be composed of account keys. Else, for accounts created with the createLedgerAccounts API,
this will be composed of the IKs of an account and its ancestors.

fields.name: unreconciledTxs
fields.description: A list of external account transactions that haven't been reconciled to this ledger account yet. Only populated for linked ledger accounts. Transactions are sorted in reverse chronological order by posted date.

types.name: LedgerAccountConsistencyConfig
types.description:
The consistency configuration of a Ledger Account's balance updates.
See [Configure consistency](https://fragment.dev/docs#configure-consistency).

fields.name: ownBalanceUpdates
fields.description:
If set to `strong`, then a Ledger Account's `ownBalance` updates will be strongly consistent with
the API response. This Ledger Account's balance will be updated and
available for strongly consistent reads once you receive an API response.

Otherwise if not set or set to `eventual`, `ownBalance` updates are applied
asynchronously and may not be immediately reflected in queries.

See [Configure consistency](https://fragment.dev/docs#configure-consistency).

types.name: LedgerAccountConsistencyConfigInput

See [Configure consistency](https://fragment.dev/docs#configure-consistency).

the API response. This Ledger Account's balance will be updated and
available for strongly consistent reads before you receive an API response.

Otherwise if unset or set to `eventual`, `lines` updates are applied
asynchronously and may not be immediately reflected queries.

See [Configure consistency](https://fragment.dev/docs#configure-consistency).

fields.name: addLedgerEntry
fields.description: Adds a Ledger Entry to a Ledger. This Ledger Entry cannot be into a Linked Ledger Account. For that, use [reconcileTx](https://fragment.dev/api-reference#mutations-reconciletx)

fields.description: Creates a Ledger.

args.name: ledger
args.description: The payload representing the Ledger to be created

args.description: The Schema to create this Ledger with

args.name: ik
args.description: The [Idempotency Key](https://fragment.dev/docs#integrate-the-api-use-idempotency)

args.name: ledger
args.description: An object containing the ID of the ledger under which to create the ledger account

args.name: ledgerAccount
args.description: The payload representing the ledger account to be created

fields.name: createLedgerAccounts
fields.description: This API call is used to create Ledger Accounts. It is only used if you are not using a Schema. Unlike other mutations that take a single IK, 'createLedgerAccount' accepts an IK for each of the ledger accounts in the request payload. This is so you can recover in the case of a partial failure.  One API call can create up to 200 Ledger Accounts, up to 10 levels deep.

args.name: ledger
args.description: An object containing the ID of the Ledger under which to create the Ledger Account.

args.name: ledgerAccounts
args.description: The list of objects representing the Ledger Accounts to be created.

fields.name: reconcileTx
fields.description: This mutation is used to [reconcile](https://fragment.dev/docs#reconcile-transactions) transactions from an external system into a Ledger Entry. This mutation does not require an idempotency key since a transaction can only be reconciled once per Linked Ledger Account.  If you are reconciling a transfer between two Link Accounts which are both linked to the same Ledger, use a transit account in between to split the transfer into two `reconcileTx` calls.

args.name: entry
args.description:
The ledger entry containing lines that specify the transaction from a linked ledger account to reconcile, as well
as the ledger account with which to offset the external transaction.

fields.name: storeSchema
fields.description:
Stores a Schema in your workspace. If no Schema with the same key exists in your worksapce, a new Schema is created.
Else, the Schema is updated, and every Ledger associated with it is migrated to the latest version.

args.name: schema
args.description: The Schema to store.

fields.name: syncCustomAccounts
fields.description: Once you've created a [Custom Link](https://fragment.dev/docs#reconcile-transactions-link-any-system), create accounts under it using this mutation. Each Custom Account is an immutable, single-entry view of all the transactions in the external account. You can sync up to 100 Custom Accounts in one API call.

args.name: accounts
args.description: A list of external accounts to sync

args.name: link
args.description: An object containing the ID of a Custom Link.

fields.name: syncCustomTxs
fields.description: You can create transactions under a Custom Account in a [Custom Link](https://fragment.dev/docs#reconcile-transactions-link-any-system) using this mutation. Once you've imported transactions, you can use the reconcileTx mutation to add them to a Ledger via the Linked Ledger Account. You can sync up to 100 Custom Transactions in one API call.

args.name: link
args.description: An object containing the ID of a Custom Link.

args.name: txs
args.description: A list of external transactions to sync

fields.name: updateLedger
fields.description: Updates a Ledger. Currently, you can change only the Ledger 'name'.

args.name: ledger
args.description: An object containing the ID of the Ledger to update.

args.name: update
args.description: A payload of fields to update. Currently, you can change only the Ledger 'name'.

fields.name: updateLedgerAccount
fields.description: Updates a ledger account. Only supports name right now.

types.name: ReadBalanceConsistencyMode
types.description:
The consistency configuration of a Ledger Account's balance queries.
If not provided as an argument to a balance query, the default behavior is to read eventually consistent balances.
See [Configure consistency](https://fragment.dev/docs#configure-consistency).

enumValues.name: eventual
enumValues.description:
Balance queries will read eventually consistent balances. This is the default behavior if `ReadBalanceConsistencyMode` is not provided as an argument to the balance field.
Both Ledger Accounts configured with strongly and eventually consistent balance updates support this enum.

enumValues.name: strong
enumValues.description: Balance queries will read strongly consistent balances. This is only allowed if the Ledger Account's `ownBalanceUpdates` in its `consistencyConfig` is `strong`.

enumValues.name: use_account
enumValues.description: Balance queries will use the value from the Ledger Account's `ownBalanceUpdates` in its `consistencyConfig`.

types.name: SchemaLedgerAccountInput
types.description:
Models a Ledger Account in a Schema.
Upon successfully storing a [Schema](https://fragment.dev/api-reference#types-core-types-schema), a [LedgerAccount](https://fragment.dev/api-reference#types-core-types-ledgeraccount) will be created for
each corresponding non-templated `SchemaLedgerAccountInput` in your Chart of Accounts.

inputFields.name: children
inputFields.description: Ledger Accounts to create as children of this Ledger Account. Ledger Accounts may be nested up to a maximum depth of 10.

inputFields.name: consistencyConfig
inputFields.description: The consistency configuration for this ledger account. See [Configure consistency](https://fragment.dev/docs#configure-consistency).

inputFields.name: currency
inputFields.description:
The currency of this Ledger Account. If this is not set, and `currencyMode` is
not set to `multi`, it is derived from the Chart of Accounts' default.

inputFields.name: currencyMode
inputFields.description: If set to `multi`, creates a multi-currency Ledger Account. If set to `single`, creates a single-currency Ledger Account.

inputFields.name: key
inputFields.description:
The key of this Ledger Account. Keys are used to formulate the unique path of the Ledger Account in your Chart of Accounts.
Siblings must have unique keys.

inputFields.name: linkedAccount
inputFields.description:
The External Account to link to this Ledger Account.
It must be provided of `linked` is true.

inputFields.name: name
inputFields.description: The human-readable name of this Ledger Account.

inputFields.name: template
inputFields.description: Whether or not this Ledger Account should be templated.

inputFields.name: type
inputFields.description: The type of ledger account to create. Required if this is a top-level Ledger Account. If not provided, the type will be inferred from the parent.

types.name: SchemaLedgerAccountMatchInput
types.description: Matches a Ledger Account in a Schema.

inputFields.name: path
inputFields.description:
The unique path of the Ledger Account in the Schema.
This is a slash-delimited string containing the keys of a Ledger Account and all its direct ancestors.
ex: expense-root/subscriptions/netflix
For Templated Ledger Accounts, you must supply a parameter in the path that will be used to name an instance of the template.
ex: `"expense-root/subscriptions/vendor:{{vendor_name}}"`

inputFields.description: A list of Ledger Entry definitions.

types.description: A condition that must be met on a Ledger Account when a Ledger Entry is posted.

inputFields.name: account
inputFields.description: The Ledger Account to apply the condition to.

inputFields.name: currency
inputFields.description:
The currency of the balance to apply the condition to. Required if the Ledger Account matched is a multi-currency Ledger Account.
Otherwise, this field is defaults to the Ledger Account's currency.

inputFields.name: postcondition
inputFields.description: A `postcondition` must be met after the Ledger Entry updates are applied.

inputFields.name: precondition
inputFields.description: A `precondition` must be met before any Ledger Entry updates are applied.

types.name: SchemaLedgerEntryInput
types.description: A Ledger Entry in a Schema. All Ledger Entries defined in a Schema must have a unique `type`.

inputFields.name: conditions
inputFields.description: Conditions that must be satisfied to post this Ledger Entry. The Ledger Entry will reject with a BadRequestError if any condition is not met. You can only add a condition on a Ledger Account containing a Line in this Ledger Entry.

inputFields.name: description
inputFields.description: Human-readable description of the Ledger Entry.

inputFields.name: groups
inputFields.description: Ledger Entries posted with this type will be in these Ledger Entry Groups.

inputFields.name: lines
inputFields.description:
The Ledger Lines in the Ledger Entry.
If provided, when posting a Typed Entry, a [LedgerEntry](https://fragment.dev/api-reference#types-core-types-ledgerline) will be posted containing [LedgerLines](https://fragment.dev/api-reference#types-core-types-ledgerline) corresponding
to the values you provide here. If your lines contain parameters, you must supply values for those parameters that balance out the Ledger Entry. If not provided, lines will be required when posting a Typed Entry.

inputFields.name: parameters
inputFields.description: Fixed partial set of parameters to be included in a templated Ledger Entry.

inputFields.name: tags
inputFields.description: Ledger Entries posted with this type will be associated with these tags.

inputFields.name: type
inputFields.description:
The type of this Ledger Entry. This is a stable, unique identifier for this entry. Uniqueness is enforced at the Schema level.
You can filter on this field when querying for Ledger Entries. See the docs on [LedgerEntryFilterSet](https://fragment.dev/api-reference#types-filter-types-ledgerentriesfilterset)

types.name: SchemaLedgerEntryTagInput
types.description: A tag associated with a Ledger Entry type.

inputFields.name: key
inputFields.description: The key for this tag.

inputFields.name: value
inputFields.description: The value associated with the given key for this tag.

types.name: SchemaLedgerLineInput
types.description: A Ledger Line in a Ledger Entry.

inputFields.name: account
inputFields.description:
The Ledger Account this Ledger Line will be posted to.
It supports parameters in its attributes via handlebars syntax.

inputFields.name: amount
inputFields.description: The amount of the Ledger Line. It supports parameters via the handlebars syntax and addition (+) and subtraction (-).

inputFields.name: currency
inputFields.description:
The currency of the Ledger Line. This is required if the Ledger Account has currencyMode multi.
It supports parameters in its attributes via handlebars syntax.

inputFields.name: description
inputFields.description: Human-readable description of the line.

inputFields.name: key
inputFields.description: The key for the Ledger Line. Ledger Line keys must be unique within a Ledger Entry. Key can be filtered on as part of the LedgerLinesFilterSet.

inputFields.name: tx
inputFields.description:
The external transaction to reconcile.
This field is required if the Ledger Account being posted to is a Linked Ledger Account. Otherwise, this field is disallowed.
It supports parameters in its attributes via handlebars syntax.

See the docs on [reconciliation and Linked Ledger Accounts](https://fragment.dev/docs#reconcile-transactions).

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields` and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

directives.name: include
directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Included when true.

directives.name: skip
directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Skipped when true.

directives.name: deprecated
directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.

args.name: reason
args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted in [Markdown](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/).
